occurrences.line_text: Abet that virgins cause disconsolate,
All arm'd to point his chalenge to abet:
The meede of thy mischalenge and abet:
To reskue him, and his weake part abet,
Abett, perhaps he mote it deare aby.
And her sowre breath abhominably smeld;
Whom Gods doe hate, and heauens abhor to see;
As the God of my life? why hath he me abhord?
Much feared I to haue bene quite abhord,
Toung hates to tell the rest, that eye to see abhord.
That had almost committed crime abhord,
And mortall vengeaunce ioyne to crime abhord?
And loathsome life, of God and man abhord,
Besides ten thousand monsters foule abhor'd
So great her pride, that she such basenesse much abhord.
Sith which she hath me euer since abhord,
But wordes, and lookes, and sighes she did abhore,
That wretched world he gan for to abhore,
Her noble bloud? the heauens such crueltie abhore.
And gan abhorre her broods vnkindly crime,
Such as by nature men abhorre and hate,
The heauens abhorre, and into darkenesse driue.
Abhorred bloudshed, and tumultuous strife,
At her abhorred face, so filthy and so fowle.
Abhorred bloudshed, and vile felony,
Abhorred Murder, who with bloudie knyfe
Eftsoones the roaring billowes still abid,
That liuing creature mote it not abide;
Infinite sorts of people did abide
Where many skilfull leaches him abide,
Then forth she rose, ne lenger would abide,
Abide, till I haue told the message, which I haue.
Might once abide the terror of that blast,
That blisse may not abide in state of mortall men.
Did in that castle afterwards abide,
But nor for gold nor glee will I abide
Which we farre off will here abide to vew.
And wakefull watches euer to abide:
Abide the fortune of thy present fate,
During the while, that Guyon did abide
But other some could not abide to toy,
But he was not so hardie to abide
Her wrathfull steele, that none mote it abide;
That in this thraldome Britons shall abide,
At least eternall meede shall you abide.
So choosing solitarie to abide,
For she list not the battell to abide,
But did abide for euer chast and sound.
And euer firmely fixed did abide
With them as housewife euer to abide,
But it would not on none of them abide,
Her list no longer in that place abide;
Which for it is too long here to abide,
Which yet with him as relickes did abide
Whereas that wofull man in languor did abide.
And entring in, found none therein abide,
But did in safe securitie abide,
But in the Porch did euermore abide
Durst not the sternnesse of his looke abide,
There did this lucklesse mayd seuen months abide,
With iron bit, and maketh him abide,
By that same carefull Squire did then abide,
So ye will sweare my iudgement to abide.
But by that Bridge, whereas he doth abide:
That his faint foe no longer could abide
In which the Paynims daughter did abide,
In which it doth immoueable abide,
Ne would within his ballaunce well abide.
Ne any token doth thereof abide:
And where, and how far hence does she abide?
And arrowes haild so thicke, that they could not abide.
The more she rag'd, the more he did abide;
Ne would abide, till she had aunswere made,
Yet being forst to abide the daies returning,
Yet mote he algates now abide, and answere make.
Ne after him did Artegall abide,
Durst not abide, but fled away for feare,
Nought may abide the tempest of his yre,
For he durst not abide with Calidore to fight.
Where she in safe assuraunce mote abide,
For bootelesse thing him seemed, to abide
Abide ye caytiue treachetours vntrew,
Abide, and from them lay your loathly hands;
Or else abide the death, that hard before you stands.
Ne durst abide the daunger of the end;
Ne durst abide behind, for dread of worse effort.
That none his daunger daring to abide,
Which not abiding, but more scornefully
His life for due reuenge should deare abie?
But patience perforce he must abie,
The which ere long full deare he shall abie.
Then letting him arise like abiect thrall,
Hauing her selfe in wretched wize abiected,
Abiecting, th'earth with his faire forhead strooke:
Through which into his darke abisse all rauin fell.
A worke of wondrous grace, and able soules to saue.
For she was able, with her words to kill,
That to the rest more able he might bee:
His deare delights were able to annoy:
Both horse and man nigh able for to choke;
Three such as able were to match a puissant host.
Which neither able were to wag, or once to weld.
That none his force were able to withstond,
Gainst whom none able was to stand on ground;
That able was weake harts away to steale.
Who able was all daungers to withstond.
Ne any able was him to withstand,
So long as these two armes were able to be wroken.
Who was not able vp him selfe to reare,
They mote the abler be to passe vnto the rest.
And there abode, whilst any beast of name
Here she a while may make her safe abode,
Where he abode, themselues at discord fell,
To make there lenger soiourne and abode;
Emongst the shadie leaues, their sweet abode,
And with her fled away without abode.
Found it the fittest soyle for their abode,
Abode, to weet what end would come of all.
AEmylia and Amoret abode,
Of that faire City, wherein make abode
And prayd the place of her abode to learne.
To make abode that night he greatly was besought.
Ne scarse wyld beasts durst come, there was this wights abode.
To moue one foote, but there must make abode;
In these wylde deserts, where she now abode,
And all their sundry kinds, and all their hid abodes.
And with thy bloud abolish so reprochfull blot.
Tho him she brought abord, and her swift bote
With his well rigged boate: They go abord,
His secret drift, till he her layd abord.
With doubled forces high aboue the ground:
With timely pride aboue the Aegyptian vale,
And mightie causes wrought in heauen aboue,
Aboue the shynie Cassiopeias chaire,
High aboue all a cloth of State was spred,
Be vnreueng'd, that calles to you aboue
Low vnder all, yet aboue all in pride,
Did loue as life, aboue all worldly blisse;
Aboue all knights on earth, that batteill vndertake.
Long he them bore aboue the subiect plaine,
With hardie fowle, aboue his hable might,
Thought with his wings to stye aboue the ground;
Aboue his wonted pitch, with countenance fell,
The same aduauncing high aboue his head,
Ne reard aboue the earth his flaming creast,
Wherewith aboue all knights ye goodly seeme aguizd.
In heauenly Registers aboue the Sunne,
Vouchsafed to behold vs from aboue,
Aboue the reason of her youthly yeares:
In wine and meats she flowd aboue the bancke,
Kindled aboue at th'heauenly makers light,
Which all aboue besprinckled was throughout,
Aboue the Moone, that fame may it resound
Her daintie limbes aboue her tender hips,
And that aboue were added to that vnder ground.
Aboue the water were on high extent,
And flourish faire aboue his equall peares;
And lifted high aboue this earthly masse,
Whose noble deedes aboue the Northerne starre
Aboue three furlongs, taking his full course,
To swell aboue the measure of his guise,
Aboue all knights, that euer battell tride,
Aboue the waters, and then downe againe
But one aboue the rest in speciall,
That fairest vertue, farre aboue the rest;
In liuing brests, ykindled first aboue,
For him he loued aboue all mankind,
And left her blisfull bowre of ioy aboue,
Fashiond aboue within their inmost part,
Forceth it swell aboue his wonted mood,
And deedes of armes aboue all Dames is deemed,
And aboue many knights is eke esteemed,
And faire resemblance aboue all the rest,
And crowne of heauenly praise with Saints aboue,
From thy sweete smyling mother from aboue,
Ouer his horses taile aboue a stryde:
Began to peepe aboue this earthly masse,
Of noble minds deriued from aboue,
Ne wist whether aboue she were, or vnder ground.
Aboue the rest, that he sometimes may space
Thence forth were brought to him aboue a score
And yet such grace is giuen them from aboue,
To whom those rolles, layd vp in heauen aboue,
And Inachus renowmd aboue the rest;
But to his bed was brought, and layd aboue,
As that it seem'd aboue the ground he went:
Doth frie with fome aboue the surges hore.
Aboue the brincke, to tread vpon the land,
And far aboue thy forces pitch to sore.
Aboue the earth vpreard his flaming head,
For whether they be placed high aboue,
There whilest he thus was setling things aboue,
Aboue a launces length him forth did beare,
Aboue all other lasses beare the bell,
Withouten her, whose worth aboue all threasure
And did with store of euery thing abound,
That cheekes with teares, and sides with bloud did all abound.
For she in pleasant purpose did abound,
Fountaines of gold and siluer to abound,
For all the sinnes, wherewith his lewd life did abound.
After their hiues with honny do abound:
With which the world did in those dayes abound:
And made there to abound with lauish affluence.
In which all pleasures plenteously abound,
To Hellenore: so busses did abound.
What time the dayes with scorching heat abound,
There whereas all the plagues and harmes abound,
That loue with gall and hony doth abound,
That all the world with goodnesse did abound:
Now when the world with sinne gan to abound,
From seeking fauour, where it doth abound;
For that it there most vseth to abound;
He through the wealth, wherein he did abound,
Of some th'aboundance of an idle braine
In great aboundance, as a well it were,
Out of her fruitfull lap aboundant flowres,
Is hardned more with my aboundant teares.
Abounded, being glad of so fit tyde
The vtmost rowme, abounding with all precious store.
Abounding all with delices most rare,
Where ease abounds, yt's eath to doe amis;
And like to lead the labyrinth about;
About her cursed head, whose folds displaid
She lookt about, and seeing one in mayle
All suddenly about his body wound,
Which swarming all about his legs did crall,
Gathred themselues about her body round,
They flocked all about her bleeding wound,
Fluttring about his euer damned hed,
He cast about, and searcht his balefull bookes againe.
That all the poison ran about his chaw;
The which he brandisheth about his hed;
Huge routs of people did about them band,
Their shining shieldes about their wrestes they tye,
And burning blades about their heads do blesse,
He sought all round about, his thirstie blade
About the bed sweet musicke did diuide,
Thence lead her forth, about her dauncing round,
And with an yuie twyne his wast is girt about.
Flocke all about to see her louely face:
About the fountaine like a girlond made;
The house of Pride, and perils round about;
Did runne about, and their felicities
From euery coast that heauen walks about,
His sparkling blade about his head he blest,
About his neck an hempen rope he weares,
And all about it wandring ghostes did waile and howle.
And all about old stockes and stubs of trees,
And throwne about the cliffs. Arriued there,
Disordred hong about his shoulders round,
And round about her head did shine like heauens light.
A multitude of babes about her hong,
He did receiue, whiles flashing fire about him shone.
That all the ayre about with smoke and stench did fill.
The wrathfull beast about him turned light,
With his broad sayles, about him soared round:
His hideous tayle then hurled he about,
But gan his sturdie sterne about to weld,
And looked all about, if she might spy
And double blowes about him stoutly laid,
About her eares, when Vna her did marke
A noble crew about them waited round
Thus flocked all the folke him round about,
His warlike armes about him gan embrace,
Till he his armes about her sides gan fold,
Did out of order stray about her daintie eares.
His sunbroad shield about his wrest he bond,
Before, behind, and round about him layes:
His puissaunt armes about his noble brest,
And many-folded shield he bound about his wrest.
They lookt about, but no where could espie
Like twinckling starres, and all the skirt about
About her shoulders weren loosely shed,
So turned her about, and fled away apace.
Turning about he saw that wretched Squire,
That round about a cloud of dust did fly,
And round about the wreath this word was writ,
And round about him threw forth sparkling fire,
The smouldring dust did round about him smoke,
And soone his dreadfull blade about he cast,
Which daintie odours round about them threw,
That round about him dissolute did play
About her necke, or rings of rushes plight;
About her litle frigot, therein making way.
The waues about, and all his armour swept,
And round about him lay on euery side
And dead mens bones, which round about were flong,
And all that preace did round about her swell,
What meant that preace about that Ladies throne,
Do flocke about, my deare my daughter is;
In a blacke flood which flow'd about it round;
And their bright Squadrons round about vs plant,
And Guyons shield about his wrest he bond;
So fierce he laid about him, and dealt blowes
Walkt round about the world, and I no lesse,
But thousand enemies about vs raue,
A thousand villeins round about them swarmd
And round about the porch on euery side
About the Caudron many Cookes accoyld,
They did about their businesse sweat, and sorely toyld.
Was fretted all about, she was arayd;
Close round about her tuckt with many a plight:
Which buzzed all about, and made such sound,
His chamber all was hangd about with rolles,
And lay strong siege about it far and wide.
And round about in fittest steades did place,
And round about him flocke impetuously,
Like two mad dogs they ran about the lands,
She turnd her bote about, and from them rowed quite.
Of harmefull fowles about them fluttering, cride,
And fatall birds about them flocked were,
About them flew, and fild their sayles with feare:
Therefore, Sir knight, your ready armes about you throw.
He hearkned, and his armes about him tooke,
Goodly it was enclosed round about,
And flew about his heeles in wanton wize,
And strowed round about, and by his side
To fly about, playing their wanton toyes,
And all the margent round about was set,
Whilst round about them pleasauntly did sing
But gathering him round about more neare,
The wals were round about apparelled
And round about it many beds were dight,
About their Lady first they flockt arownd,
And with her flaming sword about her layd,
Here, there, and euery where about her swayd
And her bright armes about her body dight:
And round about yfretted all with gold,
Kept watch and ward about her warily,
The clothes about her round with busie ayd;
And round about the pots mouth, bound the thread,
That sayd, her round about she from her turnd,
About Cairmardin, and did it commend
About her selfe she dight, that the young Mayd
The whiles the Nymphes sit all about him round,
And round about, as she could well it vze,
With mountaines round about enuironed,
Now loose about her shoulders hong vndight,
About him day and night, which doe require,
He flyes about, and with his flaggy wings
And all about grew euery sort of flowre,
Busie (as seem'd) about some wicked gin:
About her sclender wast, he tooke in hand,
To turne his steede about, or sure he should be ded.
Then drew he his bright sword, & gan about him throw.
To tucke about her short, when she did ryde,
She gathered vp and did about him dresse,
For round about, the wals yclothed were
And round about a border was entrayld,
And all about, the glistring walles were hong
And as she lookt about, she did behold,
And her welpointed weapons did about her dresse.
About her head, still roming here and there;
He looked round about with sterne disdaine;
About the chamber with that Damozell,
So soone as she was entred, round about
And all the dores to rattle round about;
At last that mightie chaine, which round about
About her backe and all her bodie wound;
Such when those Knights and Ladies all about
Which she her selfe had sowen all about,
And round about themselues a while did gaze,
And rash prouoking perils all about,
There she them found, all sitting round about
The field with listes was all about enclos'd,
About the which two Serpents weren wound,
And looking round about, like one dismaid,
And with his brondiron round about him layd;
But beaten were, and chased all about.
Might not the same about her middle weare.
Which being brought, about her middle small
Full oft about her wast she it enclos'd;
And it as oft was from about her wast disclos'd.
About their tender loynes to knit the same;
And hauing it about her middle set,
The belt againe, about her bodie gan it tie.
About the Andvile standing euermore,
About the house, at sent of stranger guest:
Yet looking round about him none could see;
And round about the same, her yellow heare
Throwes forth vpon the riuage round about him nere.
Engirt about, ne other garment wore:
Then when she lookt about, and nothing found
And with a litle golden chaine about it bound.
About the turtles necke, that with the vew
At length did marke about her purple brest
Which he in store about him kept alway,
With filthy lockes about her scattered wide,
And walke about her gardens of delight,
The morrow next about the wonted howre,
Long here and there, and round about doth stie,
And euermore his eyes about him went,
With all my might I gan to lay about:
High reared mounts, the lands about to vew;
An hundred Altars round about were set,
And all about her necke and shoulders flew
And all about her altar scattered lay
Did waite about it, gaping griesly all begor'd.
And round about him many a pretty Page
And with meet seruice waited him about;
To all about, and all her shoulders spred
But walkt abrode, and round about did rome,
For all about that rocke the sea did flow.
And romed round about the rocke in vaine,
An hundred times about the pit side fares,
Did cast about by sleight the truth thereout to straine.
Therefore the vulgar did about him flocke,
Like foolish flies about an hony crocke,
That when the people, which had there about
Amongst the flags and couert round about.
But th'emptie girdle, which about her wast was wrought.
Who round about her tender wast it fitted well.
About their middles that faire belt to knit;
Till Florimell about her fastned it.
About that wofull couple, which were slaine,
Full true it is, what so about our land
And round about his necke an halter tight,
They round about him gan to swarme apace,
Her warlike maides about her flockt so fast,
Which in great heapes them circled all about,
That shattered all to peeces round about the plaine.
A while about her with confused eye;
There entred in, he round about him saw
She quickly caught her sword, & shield about her bound.
And round about him preace in riotous aray.
But soone as he began to lay about
Hemd all about with fringe of siluer twine.
That from the Altar all about did blow
About their holy things for morrow Mas:
Full fiercely layde the Amazon about,
Whom when they heard so say, they lookt about,
And fenst himselfe about with many a flaming brand.
His charret wheeles about him whirled round,
But scattred all about, and strow'd vpon the greene.
Her brothers bones she scattered all about;
And like wyld Goates them chaced all about,
That robbed all the countrie there about,
And euer round about he cast his looke.
And round about, before her feet there sate
She was about affaires of common wele,
But walkt about them euer and anone,
Fell straight about their neckes, as they did kneele,
But shiuered all about, and scattered in the wynd.
Could wield about, that ere it were espide,
And all the vulgar did about them throng,
With his huge flaile began to lay about;
Who flocking round about them, as a swarme
And all about the fields like Squirrels hunt;
And cast his shield about, to be in readie plight.
That he therewith the knight drew all about:
Which when the people round about him saw,
That round about her iawes one might descry
Foming with poyson round about her gils,
About her eares, does beat her brest, & forhead knockes.
Into the rest, which round about you ring,
Faire Lords and Ladies, which about you dwell,
About him flockt, and hard at him did lay;
And hauing soone his armes about him dight,
Of bloudy gore congeal'd about them stood,
Wandred about the fields, as liking led
Turned his steede about another way,
And wary watch about her for her safegard keepe.
And like a wilde goate round about did chace,
But when he lookt about on euery syde,
That all about did close the compasse of his eye.
At last about the setting of the Sunne,
Where looking all about, where he mote fynd
And put them all about himselfe vnfit,
It chaunst some furniture about her steed
And heaped strokes did round about him haile
On euery side, and beat about him round;
And dangerously did round about enclose.
About the sad Serena things to dight,
So hauing all things well about her dight,
To goe about to salue such kynd of sore,
And round about with boystrous strokes oppresse,
To fight with many foes about him ment,
Turnes him about with fell auengement;
There he him found enuironed about
With which he layd about, and made them fast to flie.
And scattered all about, fell on the flowre.
Which ye may see yet all about me steeme.
He gaz'd about, and stared horriblie,
Were bound about, and voyded from before,
Traceth his ground, and round about doth beat,
Dismounting light, his shield about him threw,
The whiles that other villaine went about
And with his club him all about so blist,
Then looking round about, and seeing nought,
So round about her they them selues did place
And round about her flocke, like many flies,
Higher then all the rest, and round about
Then all the rest about her rose likewise,
That round about was bordered with a wood
Or else to course about their bases light;
The whilest the rest them round about did hemme,
Which round about her moue in order excellent.
About her daunst, sweet flowres, that far did smell,
He pypt apace, whilest they him daunst about.
With starrie beames about her shining bright,
